comments.commentBody:
It's cheating pure and simple. It's a "dive" and it hurts everyone who loves the game. Especially awful is to penalize a player for something he did not do. I've heard mostly hand-wringing and statements such as Coach Bradley (who I love and respect) that "it's a hard game to officiate." All sports have their hard spots. But to dive is unethical. End of story.

Kick every player who dives off the field for that game. Let his team play with eleven until when or if another player of the team dives in that game. Then penalize the team and keep BOTH players out oi the next game.

I saw the game where Ka Ka was ejected. Atrocious. Bad for the game and for all who want to watch that magnificent player.

I've seen one ref yelling and excoriating players to get up! To stop faking. I love that. I wish all refs did that.

Right now the culture is that cheating is ok. That needs to stop. Shame the player. Shame the team.

Yes, it's cheating, and it not only causes players to miss games; it changes outcomes, perhaps never as notoriously in the 2006 Italy-Australia round of 16 match. Of course referees should get a little wiser to the practice; in that particular game he should have said "I'm NOT deciding a match in the 93rd minute this way. Play on!"

FIFA should crack down hard on diving. My only concern is that they might start penalizing players who really do get badly fouled; the new tactic might become to foul a player in hopes he'll get yellow-carded for diving. FIFA should set up post-match reviews, as others have suggested, and issue yellow cards retroactively. Though in a tournament that might not undo the damage and become just a cost of doing business for teams looking for any way to win.
Simulation is a blight on the "Beautiful Game". It needs to be eliminated or vastly reduced. Bradely's idea is a good one and could easily be implemented. Otherwise the game is reduced to farce.

Soccer players have been "faking" injuries or faults for a long time (or, at least, since I've been watching the game).  My suggestion is to send out the "injured" player for medical assessment, and in the meantime to continue the game.  When the medical personnel send in the report, the referee will be in a better position to assess the damage, and the punishment.  No replacement until the injury is deemed real, either.  And if the injury is fake, no replacement, a red card to the faker, and a direct kick awarded to the other team.  With today's technology, it should be no problem to establish a direct line of communication between the medics and the referee.  I bet most coaches will not like the idea of a 10-member team, plus the risk of a goal against their team, b/c of a faker.  The coach or the league could also add their own punishment, like financial penalties, time out, etc.

The Jets have no excuse not to dominate.

And I'm fairly certain the entire organization agrees.

Our culture gilds head-first aggression without knowing how to deal with the concussions. The NFL and the military are case in points. Why haven't NSAIDS been studied more for this? Because the drug money is expected to come from industry while the NIH is strapped for cash?

What about aspirin? Why dont we hear more about this stuff? My father takes some UCLA bioavailable turmeric recommended by his doctor. It works like a charm. Stuff works but I would of never heard about it. Where is the government to bring us these cures?

Well done Rich:

"The thing is- it's going to happen. You take a bunch of very young men and assign them to do a job that a) requires them to violate the most basic moral and legal stricture of our society, and b) puts them in very real and immediate danger of grievous injury or death, and some of them are going to behave badly in one way or another..."

The term "gray area" surely was invented to describe the complexities of combat. A friend I made in college had been in the army in Vietnam when Lt. William Calley ordered the civilian massacre at My Lai (I was safe and warm in the Navy in Key West.) He (my friend) had also been a lieutenant in country and had seen close combat, though not with Calley.

I thought his point of view was unique. He was sympathetic to Calley. He did not condone what had happened, of course, but certainly understood HOW it might have. He had seen the gray areas himself.

He told me he never really knew which of the Vietnamese civilians were friendly and which weren't. He trusted no one. In short, he was borderline paranoid most of the time, and that was why he understood how My Lai could have happened.

I know my post has little to do with Gen. McChrystal and what happened after Tillman's death, but my friend's take on My Lai helped me at least understand in some small way why these things happen in combat and how they seem almost inevitable.

"Alternate reality?" Take me with you when you return, okay?

I agree that the match offered a very good look into Nadal's mindset and game for this tournament.  When he lost the third set, you could see steely determination settle over his face like a mask.  His serve has never been more impressive.  And the way he charged out and broke Haase in the second game of the fourth set made it very clear that Nadal is hungry to add the 2010 championship to his 2008 win.  He won the fourth set in just 22 minutes, by a score of 6-0.  My money is on Rafa.

I whole heartedly agree - Pistol Pete Sampras was and still the greates tennis player in our time and I think in Federer's time.
Federer is a good player - but then there is "Pete" the perfect stance for serving, the slice and on and on - and to the net and the scissors the list is endless.
Number One is Pete
and who
knows who will come out #2

I have some sympathy for these poor whites, but I also think they have it within their own power to improve their condition. For instance, some of the adults depicted could save money and improve their physical, mental and emotional state by giving up smoking and avoiding the abuse of intoxicants.

On the positive side, the people depicted do seem to be part of a functioning community. Life is easier when neighbors help out and look out for each other, work together and cooperate for the betterment of their community.

Another thing, correct me if I'm wrong, but haven't many white/Afrikaner children in South Africa traditionally gone barefoot? Remember Zola Budd? She raced barefoot. So I don't think it's shocking that many of these white children also go barefoot.

We stayed in the blue room for a week in Riyad Al Moussika ( www.riyad-al-moussika.com ). The room was beautiful with lovely duck down pillows and duvet and the softest of sheets. The bathroom was magnificent with an enormous walk-in bath. The rest of the Riyadh was equally beautiful. from the patio with marble fountain where we ate, to the pool, the roof terraces and the public rooms. The food was excellent and varied - French, Italian and Moroccan - with much of the food grown on the Riyadh's own farm. The manager Hassan was charming, Allal was an absolute treasure, and the rest of the staff were so helpful and friendly, and nothing was too much trouble. The location was great - very close to Jemaa el fna, and easy walking distance to most of the main sights. But you'd never know you were so close to all the hustle and bustle as it was so peaceful once inside the doors. We would thoroughly recommend a stay here.
OOooh, genetically modified salmon sounds YUMMY!

Ah, Frankenfoods.

Yes, there are advantages to genetically altered foods. However, a crucial and potentially dangerous aspect of genetically altered foodstuffs is that they may become allergenic and dangerous to certain people who suffer from life-threatening food allergies. For example, if a person is fine with mango, but has a banana allergy, and the two are combined genetically, that person may longer be able to eat mango safely.

The fact is that food allergies are on the rise, and therefore much more testing and stringent labeling will need to be done to ensure the safety of the public.

They should be put on the market, and they should be labeled as "genetically engineered." There is nothing inherently risky about genetically engineered foods, but consumers have a right to know what they're buying.

If your child grew at twice the normal rate, and looked like a 1 year old at 6 months, a 4 year old at 2 years, and a 16 year old at 8 years, you'd say there was something freakishly wrong.

These idiots are running around thinking they have improved on nature, when all they have done is tampered with her - without a clue as to the other variables they are overlooking.

Wait until something like this happens - the Frankenfish go wild and breed with other salmon types, and 5 or 10 generations out, stocks of other kinds of salmon (now inextricably interbred) suddenly collapse, as it is discovered that somehow, x number of generations down the line, the genetic modification causes the fish to perish prior to reaching maturity.

Or, name your own scenario....

The point is, or should be, only too obvious: It has taken millenia for species to evolve. Changing species overnight and testing for a year, a decade or a century, and then saying everything is bound to be OK is madness. And it is madness fed by arrogance, greed, and the basest kind of stupidity of those who think they are smart.

Idiots.

And we're bigger idiots if we let them do this.

Perhaps it would receive a "firestorm of negative response" because it deserves one. Perhaps if it cannot weather the "firestorm" the rule of democracy should be applied. Hmmm..? It will get into the wild, don't dare be deceived about that.

Great now the fishermen are out of business. Who came up with this idea man. What kinda idiots are supporting this.There is no peace. Nature is going to revolt. I wish the world ended today as if right now. I get pissed off just people being selfish. On top of this genetically engineered food is pissing me off big time. They can actually take control of the food market which they are achieving soon. Oh man Is any one even reading this stuff?
Any one want to be natural anymore? What's wrong with this world?

To allow frankenfish onto our tables without our knowledge or consent (which you know it will be) is a failure of our government, pure and simple.

When will say, "Enough!"?

It is u fortunate that genetically alterered crops and ingredients are not labeled. What if we had a choice? What would we choose. Milk is labeled so we have a choice. We have c hoise between Farm raised, wild caught, atlantic, and alaskan river salmon. So why in the world would we not have a choice between natural and labaratory alterered.

“Our fish is identical in every measurable way to the traditional food Atlantic salmon,” Mr. Stotish said. “If there’s no material difference, then it would be misleading to require labeling.

Every measurable way except how it was concieved, the rate of growth, and the fact that they are raised inland and are all sterile cloned females. If there is a fear of their mixing with wild stock then clearly they are diferent enoigh to require labeling.

As a consumer, I want to know. And PS Mr. Stoish if you believe in your product what are you afraid of?

I think I saw this on the SyFy channel:
Scientist 1: "It won't get any bigger than a regular salmon."
Scientist 2: "Yeah, there's no way it can cause any---AAAAAHHHHH!" [Salmon the size of a school bus leaps from the water, eats scientist.)

The only way, in the end, to test whether something is not dangerous is to have humans eat it for fifty years and see what develops.  Do we really want pregnant women, children, other citizens to eat something pumped with hormones to make it grow faster/bigger?  There really isn't any way for the FDA to truly say that this will  not be harmful.

If independent tests confirm that they are identical to natural salmon, then they are a godsend for a world in which fish stocks are being depleted.

Also, I'll bet they are delicious smoked.
The minute they approve that Salmon, I'll stop buying ANY salmon.

genetically altered foods cannot be contained besides the obvious health and safety issues we are impacting our environment irreversibly

havent we learned by now that playing god with nature doesnt work
there arent any substitutes for conservation.

This is sick, disturbing stuff! Mad scientists! I know now that we cannot rely on the Federal Government to protect us from anything. I thought farmed fish was bad enough, now this? Is there nothing that they will not do for the almighty freak'in dollar? No more salmon for me.
